attributes.alt: Book cover for Follow that Garbage! A Journey to the Landfill by Bridget Heos and illustrated by Alex Westgate. The cover art shows a garbage truck going down the street.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
Read for enjoyment, pointing out the different shapes in the book.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Show children three different shapes that they will identify and name.
Have children identify shapes and their attributes in a matching activity.
How can we care for our world?
What book did you choose? What is the book about?
Pretend to drive a garbage truck. Where are you going?
Can you make a circle shape with your fingers? What makes it a circle?
Can you write about what happens to garbage after we throw it away?
What shapes do you see in your creation?
Which letters do you see two times in the word
What are you building? Can you make a square shape with blocks?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to reinforce following rules and routines and to recognize shapes.
Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Use technology to find information; Use digital tools and resources safely; Show understanding of common technology and how it affects how people live.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Ask children to follow a rule for creating an image with Pattern Blocks.
Instruct children to include a set number of a specific shape in their work.
How can we care for our world?
What community is in that book?
Pretend to be following a garbage truck’s routine.
Can you show me some circles and squares in the room?
What is your community like? Can you write about it?
Draw a shape. What shape did you make?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the name of your favorite shape?
Why did you make that shape with those blocks?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Follow that Garbage! A Journey to the Landfill by Bridget Heos and illustrated by Alex Westgate. The cover art shows a garbage truck going down the street.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about solid shapes, have children identify shapes, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question,
What happens to the garbage after it gets picked up?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and further exploration of shapes in the book.
Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Ask children to identify and name objects that are solid shapes.
Have children identify shapes and their attributes in a matching activity.
How can we care for our world?
Can you show me some shapes in that book?
Pretend to be a bouncy ball. What shape are you?
Try and put two triangles together to make another shape.
Write about a garbage truck driver’s job.
Can you draw a picture that has circles and squares in it?
Can you find three things in the room that start with the same beginning sound as
What can you build with box-shaped blocks?

attributes.alt: The Big Chart of Big Ideas for You Can Help. The cover has a flower with a picture in each petal that shows a girl with her hand on a water faucet; a child handing a toy to another child; children recycling; a child growing plants; a child turning off a light switch, and a child driving a toy train.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas:  You Can Help

elements.text: Earth and Space Science; Life Science
Use Circle Time to discuss protecting the Earth and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to geometry by pointing out different shapes.
Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.
Use technology to find information; Use digital tools and resources safely; Show understanding of common technology and how it affects how people live.
Earth and Space Science;  Life Science
Review solid shape images with children.
Have children find examples of solid shapes in the classroom and describe them.
How can we care for our world?
What was your favorite part of that book?
What sounds would you make if you were being a garbage truck? What is the best part of being a garbage truck?
This shape is bigger than this one. Are they both triangles?
Write about the Earth. What is special about it?
Draw a picture with two of your favorite shapes.
Draw a letter. Can you think of something in the room that starts with that letter?
What solid shapes are you building with?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Follow that Garbage! A Journey to the Landfill by Bridget Heos and illustrated by Alex Westgate. The cover art shows a garbage truck going down the street.

elements.text: Earth and Space Science;  Life Science
Use Circle Time to connect the book to language and to play a guessing game with children about shapes.
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
How can we help make less garbage?
Read and retell the story interactively for physical engagement and a focus on shapes.

Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles; Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
What can we do to protect the Earth?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How can we care for our world?
What kind of book do you imagine you want to read next?
What is something you could do with a cardboard box? Can you think of anything else?
What shape is this? What shape will you create if you combine shapes?
Write a story about caring for the Earth.
Can you create a picture of a garbage truck? What shapes are in it?
What sounds do you hear in the word
? Write all the letters that you hear.
Build a place where people can recycle their old things.
